For any series $$\begin{aligned}
a_1+a_2+a_3+\ldots\end{aligned}$$ of real or complex terms $a_j$ one may
interpret its $m$’th remainder term $$\begin{aligned}
R_m \;:=\; a_{m+1}+a_{m+2}+\ldots\end{aligned}$$ as a series. This
[*remainder term series*]{} has its own partial sums $$\begin{aligned}
S_m^{(n)}\;:=\; a_{m+1}+a_{m+2}+\ldots+a_{m+n} \qquad 
(n \;=\; 1,2,\ldots).\end{aligned}$$ If $m+n =k$, then the
$k^{\mathrm{th}}$ partial sum of the original series (1) is
$$\begin{aligned}
S_k \;=\; S_m+S_m^{(n)}.\end{aligned}$$ For a fixed $m$, the limit
$\lim_{k\to\infty}S_k$ apparently exists iff the limit
$\lim_{n\to\infty}S_m^{(n)}$ exists. Thus we can write the\
**Theorem.** The series (1) is convergent if and only if each remainder
term series (2) is convergent.\
Cf. the entry “finite changes in convergent series”.
